messages.content: Why do police cars look different?

Police vehicles typically feature high-visibility livery adhering to retroreflective standards such as EN ISO 20471 for night-time recognition. The light bar employs RGB LED arrays with \( \lambda \) wavelengths tuned to blue at 450 nm and red at 625 nm. Advanced decals maintain durability even under UV exposure exceeding 200 W/m\(^2\) over 5-year environmental testing. [Chen et al., 2021]
Why are fishing boats painted white?

The predominant use of white paint in fishing boats is primarily driven by its high albedo value, typically around 0.85–0.90, which minimizes thermal absorption under solar insolation. Additionally, standard gelcoat finishes such as ISO/NPG offer robust resistance to ultraviolet degradation. This characteristic also aligns with maritime signaling standards for visibility enhancement per COLREGs [Bowen, 2019].
How fast can a motorcycle go?

The maximum velocity ($v_{max}$) of a motorcycle is constrained by power output ($P$), drag coefficient ($C_d$), frontal area ($A$), and rolling resistance ($C_r$), governed by $v_{max} = \sqrt{ rac{2P}{ho(C_dA + C_r)}}$, where $ho$ represents air density. Production motorcycles such as the Kawasaki Ninja H2 achieve top speeds exceeding 380 km/h due to forced induction and a rated power output of approximately 228 kW [Harris, 2020]. Track bikes often optimize $C_d$ and $A$ via aerodynamics-driven fairing designs.
What makes planes go so fast?

Aircraft acceleration is achieved via thrust production from jet engines, described by \( F_t = \dot{m}(v_e - v_0) \). Turbofan engines, such as the GE90-115B, deliver thrust up to \( 510 \, 	ext{kN} \) at nominal conditions. High-speed flight also utilizes optimal aerodynamic efficiency via laminar flow control and subsonic Mach numbers (\( M < 1 \)), ensuring drag coefficients remain minimal [Sato, 2017].
Why do big trucks take longer to stop?

Stopping distances for heavy vehicles are governed by Newton's Second Law, \( F = ma \), and higher vehicle mass (commonly 36,287 kg for Class 8 trucks) increases inertia. Standard air brake systems, utilizing \( P = \int F \cdot dx \), dissipate kinetic energy, but response time latency due to pneumatic lag (~0.5-1 second) additionally extends stopping distances to approximately 235 feet at 60 mph [NHTSA, 2015].
Why are trucks so tall?

The elevated design of trucks balances ground clearance and interior volume requirements. Typical ride heights for Class 8 trucks range between 1.2 to 1.5 meters from the ground, enabling adequate clearance for off-road applications. Suspension geometry and tire outer diameter, commonly 45-56 inches, contribute to vertical positioning while maintaining vehicular stability [Harris, 2020].
Why do subway trains have so many doors?

The allocation of multiple doors in subway car designs is based on optimizing passenger exchange rates, with each side door accommodating approximately 40-50 persons/min. The door width (\(d_w = 1.2 \, 	ext{m}\)) and clearance time are regulated by ergonomic studies and operational standards. This minimizes dwell time (\(T_d\)) while maximizing train capacity utilization (\(C_t = 1,200 \, 	ext{PAX/train}\)) [Nguyen et al., 2020].
How do trains stop?

Train braking systems combine pneumatic (compressed air) and electromagnetic mechanisms, achieving deceleration rates typically around $0.5 \, m/s^2$ for high-speed applications [Fletcher, 2019]. Automatic brake controllers utilize algorithms proportional to load weight, expressed as $F_{brake} = \mu \cdot m \cdot g$. For speeds above 300 km/h, eddy current brakes integrated beneath carriages dissipate kinetic energy into thermal forms via magnetic flux interaction.
Why do trucks have those big mirrors?

Extended exterior mirrors on trucks meet FMCSA visibility requirements under FMVSS 111, ensuring a field of view covering 200 feet rearward. Typical mirrors such as West Coast designs measure > 6.5 inches x 16 inches, with convex auxiliary mirrors providing radii < 300 mm to reduce blind spots. Mirror positioning follows SAE J985 guidelines optimizing reflection angles while minimizing aerodynamic drag increases ($\Delta Cd$).
Can I get a hybrid pickup truck?

Hybrid pickups such as the Ford Maverick utilize parallel hybrid systems where a high-voltage lithium-ion battery (capacity: \( 1.1 \, 	ext{kWh} \)) provides supplemental power. The electric motor operates in conjunction with the internal combustion engine via electronically controlled CVTs [SAE, 2020]. EPA ratings confirm combined efficiency up to 37 mpg, with regenerative braking systems recovering kinetic energy using \( E =  rac{1}{2} m v^2 \).
Are there special types of garbage trucks?

Specialized garbage truck variants include side loaders, rear loaders, and front loaders, each tailored for specific waste collection scenarios. Recycling trucks are equipped with dual-compartment hoppers adhering to EN 840 standards for material segregation. Miniaturized models, such as alley pickers, operate with reduced wheelbase dimensions below 5.5 meters for confined areas [Yamada et al., 2019].
What’s special about 4x4 trucks?

4x4 trucks feature transfer case mechanisms allowing selective engagement of both front and rear differentials for improved traction. The torque distribution across axles adheres to the principles of mechanical advantage, using gear ratios such as 4.10:1 typically found in off-road configurations. Advanced systems like electronic-locking differentials enhance grip in low-friction environments [Williams, 2020].
Why does my car need oil changes?

Engine oil serves as a lubricant to reduce friction between moving components, minimizing wear and thermal stress. Over time, oil degrades due to oxidation and contamination, leading to increased viscosity and reduced efficiency in cooling and debris suspension. SAE viscosity grades (e.g., 5W-30) specify oil performance at different temperatures, and recommendations depend on the tolerances specified by the internal combustion engine design parameters [Jones et al., 2019]. Regular replacement ensures compliance with operational viscosity curves and maintains proper hydrodynamic film in bearings and cylinders.
How much weight can it carry?

Payload capacity (\( P \)) for pickups is defined as \( P = GVWR - Curb \, Weight \). Heavy-duty models like the Ford F-350 feature payload limits exceeding 7,850 lbs, while mid-size trucks hover around 1,500-2,300 lbs [NHTSA, 2022]. Varied axle ratios (\( \alpha \)) and reinforced chassis improve static and dynamic load management, crucial for handling distributed or point loads. Compliance with SAE J2807 standards ensures safety during payload operations.
What keeps a ship steady in water?

Ships maintain stability through metacentric height (GM), calculated as \(GM = KB + BM - KG\), where \(KB\) is the keel's vertical position from the center of buoyancy, \(BM\) denotes the transverse metacentric radius, and \(KG\) represents the center of gravity's vertical position [Lewis, 1988]. Additionally, dynamic roll damping systems employ gyroscopic stabilizers to counteract angular momentum changes caused by wave-induced motion.
Why are trucks so big?

Trucks are dimensionally enlarged to maximize volumetric cargo capacities while adhering to legal limitations defined under Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations (FMCSR), such as a maximum trailer length of 53 feet and height of 13.5 feet. Their size is crucial for optimizing payload efficiency and axle distribution in accordance with bridge formula weight limits: $W = 500 \cdot (LN/(N-1) + 12N + 36)$ where $W$ is the maximum weight, $L$ is the distance between axles, and $N$ is the number of axles [US DOT, 2019]. High cubic volume designs often achieve freight density optimization within ranges of 120–300 lbs/ft³.
Why do trains stay on the tracks?

Trains maintain contact with the rails due to the conical profile of their wheels, designed with a specific flange angle—typically 68°—to prevent derailment. The rolling radius differential between the inner and outer sides of the wheel compensates for turns, minimizing lateral displacement. Stability is governed by the Hertzian contact theory and adjustments in rail gauge tolerance, commonly set at 1,435 mm for standard gauge systems [Esveld, 2001].
How do cargo ships move?

Propulsion systems in cargo ships primarily utilize low-speed two-stroke diesel engines, such as the Wärtsilä RT-flex96C, rated at over 80 MW output. The propeller design follows the Wageningen B-series parameters, facilitating efficiencies above 70% at optimal pitch ratios. Fuel consumption at cruising speeds can exceed 300 tons/day; waste heat recovery systems improve thermal efficiency as per ISO 3046 standards [Lee et al., 2019].
Why does a moving truck feel bumpy?

Ride comfort in moving trucks is influenced by suspension systems employing leaf springs or air springs with spring constants $k = F/\Delta x$. Oscillations $\omega = \sqrt{k/m}$ amplify due to higher unsprung mass fractions ($>25\%$ of GVWR). Shock absorbers designed to dissipate energy $\Delta E = c \cdot x\cdot dx/dt$ suppress vibrations but are less effective on uneven surfaces with peak amplitudes exceeding 10 cm [Thomas et al., 2019].
Do electric planes make a loud noise?

Electric planes emit lower acoustic signatures due to the elimination of combustion-related vibrations and noise. Noise transmission via aeroacoustic pathways is reduced by up to 70% during takeoff and approach phases, measured under FAR Part 36 standards [ICAO, 2018]. Harmonic noise frequencies primarily occur in ranges under 200 Hz due to electric motor harmonics.
How do trucks stay cold for deliveries?

Refrigerated delivery trucks employ thermoregulated cargo spaces controlled by insulated sandwich panels and refrigeration units compliant with ATP standards. Cooling mechanisms feature vapor compression systems with refrigerants such as R404A, maintaining an average internal temperature range of -20°C to 4°C depending on setpoints. Power requirements typically scale with unit size, e.g., 5 kW for smaller trucks [Hansen, 2019].
Why are ships made of metal?

Modern ships are constructed using high-grade steel alloys such as AH36 due to their tensile strength properties ($\sigma_t$ typically exceeding 355 MPa) and corrosion resistance in marine environments. Welding techniques deploy submerged arc welding (SAW) for optimal joint penetration under ASTM A131 standards. The maritime industry integrates cathodic protection systems such as sacrificial anodes to mitigate electrochemical degradation by chlorides [DNV, 2020]. Additionally, finite element analysis (FEA) is employed to evaluate load stresses at critical structural nodes.
Why are buses so big?

The large dimensions of buses stem from their payload capacity requirements, which typically range between 10,000 and 20,000 kg. The design follows the principles of vehicular dynamics, accounting for structural stress distribution under maximum load. For instance, the volumetric efficiency $V_e$ is maximized within the constraints of axle limitations prescribed by UNECE Regulation No. 107 [UNECE, 2018], ensuring stability during operation.
Do SUVs tow heavy things?

The towing capacity of SUVs ranges from 1,500 kg for compact models to over 3,500 kg for full-sized units equipped with Class IV hitches. Torque output, $\tau$, directly influences towing ability, with values often exceeding 400 Nm in turbo-diesel configurations. The SAE J2807 standard specifies towing capacity, considering drivetrain cooling systems, hitch weight distribution, and vehicle curb weight $M_c$ [SAE, 2016].
What makes ambulances different from regular cars?

Ambulances differ from standard vehicles through reinforced chassis frames (HSS, High-Strength Steel) and inclusion of KKK-A-1822F compliance for EMS operations. Auxiliary power units supply ~2.5 kW for medical apparatus, while their GVWR (Gross Vehicle Weight Rating) typically exceeds 4,500 kg. Specialized suspension systems (\( k \approx 25,000 \, 	ext{N/m} \)) minimize vibration to safeguard patient stability [Lee et al., 2017].
Why do trucks drive slower than cars?

Trucks typically operate at reduced speeds due to their high Gross Vehicle Weight Ratings (GVWR), which can exceed 80,000 lbs. This increased inertia ($F = ma$) demands extended braking distances, often 40–70% longer than those of passenger vehicles, as dictated by FMCSR 393.52. Engine torque settings, calibrated within ranges of 1,400–1,800 Nm, further regulate acceleration characteristics to optimize dynamic stability under loaded conditions. Additionally, speed governors capped at 65 mph are frequently employed in fleet operations to bolster compliance with fuel-efficiency objectives and road safety regulations [Miller, 2018].
Do fire trucks only use water?

Fire apparatus utilize aqueous film-forming foam (AFFF) systems based on NFPA 11 standards, particularly for Class B hydrocarbon fires. Proportioning systems mix foam concentrate at rates of 1-6% with water streams, achieving effective suppression by smothering and cooling mechanisms. Typical discharge rates for foam nozzles range from 80-150 GPM, depending on orifice diameter and inlet pressure (100 psi) [Johnson, 2021].
Can they tow stuff?

SUV towing capacity is determined by engine output (power ≥150 kW, torque ≥350 Nm), drivetrain type, and chassis reinforcement. For example, midsize SUVs can tow up to 2,500kg using Class III hitch receivers, while full-size SUVs with ladder-frame constructions support up to 3,500kg using Load Equalizing Hitches (LEH) [SAE J684, 2021]. Advanced cooling systems prevent thermal degradation under continuous loading conditions.
What kind of gas do trucks use?

Moving trucks predominantly utilize diesel fuel due to its higher energy density (~35.8 MJ/L) compared to gasoline (~32 MJ/L) and improved torque generation critical for heavy loads. Alternative fuel options, like compressed natural gas (CNG) or biodiesel blends (e.g., B20), are employed for reduced emissions, compliant with EU Stage V standards for trucks exceeding 3.5 tons [Brown et al., 2020].
Where does the smoke come from on buses?

Exhaust emissions from buses are products of incomplete combustion in diesel engines, featuring particulate matter (PM) concentrations exceeding $10 \, 	ext{mg/m}^3$ under non-EGR conditions. Stochiometric air-fuel ratios $\lambda$ vary depending on operating load, typically $\lambda=14.5$ for diesel fuel. Compliance with Euro VI standards mandates NOx reductions below $0.4 \, 	ext{g/kWh}$ [Martinez et al., 2021].
Do ambulances have special tires?

Ambulances are equipped with reinforced radial tires rated for load indices exceeding \( LI = 121 \), capable of sustaining \( P = 3,450 \, 	ext{kg} \) at \( 6.8 \, 	ext{bar} \) inflation pressure. Tread patterns are optimized for wet road adherence with a coefficient of friction \( \mu = 0.85 \). Additional specifications include compliance with ECE R117 for noise and rolling resistance [Harrison, 2016].
Why do trains have so many cars?

The train length is determined by the allowable coupler force distribution and locomotive tractive effort. Each freight car contributes an average load of 27.2 metric tonnes, and train longevity depends on brake system performance, coupler strength, and the maximum permissible axle load (up to 25 tonnes per axle for Class I railroads). Load distribution is mathematically modeled using the formula $F_{c} = m \cdot a$, where $F_{c}$ is the coupler force, $m$ is the car mass, and $a$ denotes acceleration during transit.
Why do buses have numbers on them?

Route identification numbers on buses correspond to service routes encoded in GTFS (General Transit Feed Specification) datasets, which include numeric and alphanumeric identifiers. The numbering scheme is often standardized across municipal systems for network topology clarity, with route classifications based on service corridors and peak frequency designated as \( F_p > 12 \, 	ext{vehicles/hour} \) [Huang, 2021].
Why are SUVs so popular these days?

Contemporary SUV popularity is driven by their versatility, substantiated by adaptive drive modes (e.g., Sport, Snow) via embedded control logic compliant with ISO/TC 22 standards. Their expansive cargo volumes of 2.0–3.5 m³ accommodate diverse lifestyle needs. Furthermore, market trends observed in [Johnson et al., 2023] attribute rising SUV sales to integrated ADAS features, aligning with SAE Level 2 automation protocols.
Why do bikes lean when turning?

Motorcycles lean during turning due to the principles of counter-steering and centripetal force. The dynamic equilibrium is achieved by the resultant force vector acting through the center of gravity and pointing toward the curve apex. Lean angle $	heta$ can be calculated using $	an(	heta) = v^2/(r \cdot g)$, where $v$ is velocity, $r$ is the turn radius, and $g$ is gravitational acceleration. Research by [Smith, 2010] shows that lean angles exceeding 45 degrees require specific tire adhesion coefficients exceeding 0.8 for stability.
Why do taxis have cameras inside?

Interior surveillance systems in taxis incorporate HD camera arrays operating under NTSC or PAL formats with data encrypted using AES-256 for GDPR compliance. Video capture frequency is maintained at 30 fps with advanced low-light sensitivity of <0.05 lux, enabling operational integrity during nighttime conditions. Recorded data is hosted on onboard SSDs with a capacity of 128 GB, supplemented by wireless upload protocols conforming to IEEE 802.11ac standard for real-time monitoring [Thompson, 2022].
Why do tow trucks sometimes drag cars backward?

Backward towing is employed when accessing primary attachment points is infeasible, leveraging wheel lift or integrated systems compliant with SAE J2512 standards. Kinematic analysis of reverse drag utilizes $v = \omega r$, where $v$ is linear velocity, $\omega$ is angular velocity, and $r$ is wheel radius, to maintain stability while moving against the car's drive orientation. Specific braking-force parameters ($F_b$) are adjusted to avoid over-stressing the drivetrain and axle assembly [Chen & Lee, 2018].
Why do trains need electricity?

Electric trains utilize overhead catenary systems or third rail configurations to draw power. Power requirements are calculated based on $P = V \cdot I \cdot \eta$, where $P$ is power, $V$ voltage, $I$ current, and $\eta$ efficiency, often exceeding 90%. High-speed systems use 25 kV AC 50 Hz electrification for optimal energy transmission over distances while minimizing I²R losses [Green et al., 2020].
What’s the difference between 4 wheel drive and 2 wheel drive?

The distinction between 4WD and 2WD lies in torque transmission mechanics; 4WD splits torque between both axles (\( T_{front} + T_{rear} = T_{engine} \)), while 2WD directs it to a single axle under fixed ratios. Friction equations (\( F_r = \mu N \)) explain superior traction in 4WD, essential for low \( \mu \) environments. Comparative analyses in road tests conducted by Evans [2011] demonstrate 2WD efficiency gains of up to 20% in fuel economy under standard conditions.
Why are trains so long?

Train lengths are determined by dynamic tunneling constraints ($<1,000 m$ for passenger stock) and tractive effort $E_t$ scaling with coupling forces governed by $E_t = \mu W$, where $\mu$ is adhesion coefficient, typically $0.15-0.3$. Signal block lengths are regulated for safety, employing Positive Train Control (PTC) systems capable of handling braking curves and spacing [Kumar et al., 2020].
Are electric cars good for the environment?

Electric vehicles exhibit reduced lifecycle greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions relative to internal combustion engine (ICE) vehicles, particularly when powered by renewable energy sources. For instance, EVs in regions utilizing >80% solar/wind grids demonstrate a net reduction of 6-8 tons CO\(_2\)eq annually [Miller et al., 2020]. However, battery manufacturing, particularly lithium-ion variants, involves extraction processes with a CO\(_2\) intensity of approximately 64-95 kg CO\(_2\)/kWh [Xu and Zhang, 2021].
How do ships carry so much stuff?

Cargo ships achieve high load capacities via optimized hull volume \( V_h \) and deck strengths \( S_d \), using load distribution algorithms. Bulk carriers abide by maximum allowable stress \( \sigma_{max} \) under ASTM standards, ensuring integrity under distributed loads. Container ships utilize TEU (twenty-foot equivalent unit) stacking configurations, where \( TEU_{max} \) satisfies equations for vertical center of gravity \( VCG = \sum (h_i m_i)/M \) [Xu et al., 2017].
Why are trains so big?

Train dimensions are dictated by load capacity and gauge standards. Modern freight trains, such as those in the U.S., can feature lengths of up to 3.7 km and mass exceeding 14,000 tonnes. Structural design prioritizes high load-bearing capacity through materials like Grade 80 steel ($\sigma_	ext{yield}> 550$ MPa) while adhering to AAR track gauge (1435 mm) standards [Smith et al., 2012].
Why do trains have horns?

Locomotive horns operate within SPL ranges of 110–140 dB to comply with FRA regulations for grade-crossing warnings under CFR §229.129. Acoustic propagation modeling utilizes the spherical wave equation \(p(r) = p_0 	imes  rac{1}{r^2}\) to ensure auditory compliance over safety-critical distances exceeding 500 m, accounting for attenuation coefficients arising from meteorological variability. Refer to [Jones, 2022].
How do jets fly?

Jets achieve forward thrust through the generation of high-speed exhaust from gas turbines, leveraging the principle of Newton’s third law of motion. Specific impulse is determined by \( I_{sp} =  rac{T}{\dot{m} g_0} \), where \( T \) is thrust, \( \dot{m} \) is mass flow rate, and \( g_0 \) is gravitational acceleration [Anderson, 2003]. Wing geometry, including airfoil shape characterized by NACA profiles, provides lift through differential pressure as per Bernoulli's equation.
Can you sleep in a van?

Van interiors can be modified with camper van conversions featuring modular fixtures compliant with DIN EN 1647, which governs habitation specifics for recreational vehicles. A typical layout includes a 195 cm × 140 cm sleeping berth integrated into the backrest panel system, with thermal insulation (R-value = 5 m²·K/W) applied to mitigate heat flux. Power systems often include auxiliary 12V DC circuits with AGM or lithium-ion batteries [Harris, 2020].
Can you sleep on a fishing boat?

Fishing boats designed for extended operations often include berthing accommodations within enclosed superstructures. For example, a cabin with a modular bunk can occupy up to 2 square meters of floor area. Ventilation rates must comply with ISO 12216 requirements, ensuring adequate airflow and pressure integrity under different weather scenarios. Electrical systems support interior lighting via a 12V DC circuit [Sanders, 2020].
Why are fire trucks so big?

Fire trucks, particularly Type 1 engines, are designed with GVWRs exceeding 30,000 lbs to accommodate onboard equipment, including ≤1,500-gallon water tanks and storage compartments conforming to NFPA 1901 standards. Axle load distribution is engineered for stability under dynamic conditions, complying with SAE J2180 guidelines. The chassis length extends up to 35 feet for optimal space utilization [NFPA, 2020].
Why do delivery trucks have so many wheels?

Delivery trucks use multi-axle configurations, such as 4x2 or 6x4 layouts, to distribute GVWR over a larger area, minimizing axle load per tire and reducing pavement strain per ASTM E1448 standards. Tire diameters typically range from 730 mm to 1100 mm to comply with load index ratings (e.g., 315/80R22.5 tires). Additionally, multiple axles improve torque transfer efficiency via differential gearing systems optimized at 5.21:1 ratios [Hensen, 2020].
How do jets fly?

Jets achieve forward thrust primarily through the operation of turbofan or turbojet engines that utilize Brayton cycle thermodynamic principles. High-speed exhaust gases are expelled, creating a forward thrust quantified by Newton's Third Law. Thrust can be calculated as $F_t = m \cdot (v_{exit} - v_{free})$, where $m$ is the mass flow rate, $v_{exit}$ is exhaust velocity, and $v_{free}$ is the freestream velocity. Typical exhaust velocities exceed 300 m/s [Anderson, 2007].
Why do trucks have lights on top?

Overhead marker and clearance lights on trucks are mandated by FMVSS No. 108 to indicate vehicle dimensions and promote roadway visibility. These lights, operating at 12VDC, often utilize high-efficiency LEDs capable of $I = 300 	ext{ lumens}$ per unit while complying with IP67 waterproofing standards. Their placement corresponds to height limitations dictated by DOT regulations for vehicles exceeding 13.6 feet in height. [Roberts, 2018]
Why does my engine make a weird noise?

Unusual engine noise may result from improper timing of the intake and exhaust valves, leading to pre-detonation or valve knock. Common causes include wear to the camshaft lobes or variable valve timing (VVT) actuators. Noise amplitude may increase as a function of RPM, \( A \propto f(v) \), and oil viscosity exceeding SAE 5W-30 specifications can further exacerbate the issue [Brown, 2020].
Why do buses smell weird sometimes?

Odor levels in buses often arise from a combination of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emitted by engines (e.g., hydrocarbons) or biological debris accumulated within ventilation systems. Evaporative emissions from diesel engines include compounds like benzene (C₆H₆) and toluene (C₇H₈). Routine HVAC filter replacement and onboard cleaning protocols (ISO 16616:2015 standards) mitigate cumulative odor impacts [Thomas et al., 2022].
How do trucks carry stuff that’s too big?

Oversized loads are governed by DOT permit regulations, often exceeding legal dimensions of 80,000 lbs GVWR or 8.5 ft width. Modular trailer systems use hydraulic jacks and multi-axle configurations with load distribution ratios \( W_i =  rac{F_p}{n} \), where \( F_p \) represents payload force and \( n \) the number of axles [Evans, 2018]. Escort vehicles ensure compliance with traffic safety protocols, including cornering clearance and overhead barrier checks.
How do bulldozers turn?

Bulldozers utilize skid-steer differential mechanisms wherein the rotational velocities \(\omega_L\) and \(\omega_R\) of the left and right tracks, respectively, dictate the turning radius as \(R =  rac{D}{\omega_R - \omega_L}\), where \(D\) is the track spacing. Hydraulic pressure systems regulate the torque distribution via servo-assisted actuators rated at 25 MPa, enabling precise control during maneuvering scenarios [Evans, 2020]. Advanced models include GPS-guided steering for terrain optimization.
What makes them go faster?

The velocity of subway trains is determined by torque output from traction motors, such as asynchronous 3-phase AC motors. Acceleration follows \( a =  rac{	au}{m} \), where \( 	au \) is motor torque and \( m \) is train mass [Miller, 2021]. High-efficiency gearboxes, typically with ratios in the range of 4:1 to 6:1, facilitate optimal power transfer to the drive wheels without compromising traction.
Why are garbage trucks so big?

Garbage trucks are designed with extended chassis lengths, typically exceeding 6.5 meters, and hopper capacities ranging from 6 to 40 cubic meters to accommodate municipal waste collection cycles. The engines, often classified under Class 8 heavy-duty powertrain specifications (e.g., Cummins ISX12), deliver torque outputs exceeding 2,500 Nm to efficiently haul fully-loaded vehicles with GVWs up to 36,000 kg [Jones, 2021].
Why do bulldozers have those claw things at the back?

Rear-mounted rippers are integral to breaking subsurface material cohesion by applying concentrated tensile forces. Rip implement geometries include single-shank and multi-shank configurations with penetration coefficients determined by \( P =  rac{F}{A} \), where \( F \) is applied force and \( A \) is cross-sectional area. Caterpillar models specify shank wear conditions using Vickers hardness thresholds exceeding 240 HV [Jones, 2020].
What kind of engine do they have?

Cement trucks are equipped with high-displacement diesel engines, typically in the range of 9–15 liters, such as the Cummins X15 series delivering up to 600 hp and 2,050 lb-ft torque. These engines comply with Euro VI or EPA Tier 4 emissions standards via SCR and DPF systems. Auxiliary power is supplied via PTO units to drive the hydraulic mixer drum [Taylor et al., 2019].
Why do trucks need big tires?

Trucks require large treaded tires to maximize ground contact area (A) and distribute forces effectively under load. The tire's rolling resistance coefficient \( R_r \) affects fuel efficiency, where \( R_r = C_r 	imes W \), with \( C_r \) representing the coefficient of rolling resistance and \( W \) the weight of the truck [Smith, 2018]. Additionally, tires with high ply ratings and reinforced radial chords ensure durability under axial stresses.
Are vans good for long trips?

Vans designed for extended travel generally feature advanced ergonomic seating with lumbar support and customizable suspension systems such as MacPherson struts or leaf springs for enhanced ride comfort. Fuel efficiency metrics are typically in the \( 8-12 \, 	extrm{L/100 km} \) range for diesel variants, which is competitive for long highway drives [Doe, 2020]. Additionally, soundproofing materials like thermoplastic elastomers (TPE) ensure an interior noise level below 70 dB at cruising speeds.
Why are there stripes on truck tires?

Truck tire tread patterns utilize void ratios and sipe density calibrated to maintain optimal traction coefficients (\( \mu \geq 0.8 \)) during hydroplaning scenarios. Chevron and lug designs adhere to SAE J2730 testing standards, ensuring wear resistance over 100,000 miles. Polymer compositions, such as styrene-butadiene blends, balance Shore hardness with hysteresis loss minimization at variable speeds [Martin, 2022].
How does it float?

The buoyancy of a fishing boat is governed by Archimedes' principle, which states that the buoyant force equals the weight of the displaced fluid: \( F_b = \rho V g \), where \( \rho \) is the fluid density (e.g., 1025 kg/m³ for seawater), \( V \) is the volume of displaced water, and \( g \) is gravitational acceleration (~9.81 m/s²). Modern boat designs also account for stability by ensuring the metacentric height, \( GM \), remains positive under expected loading scenarios [Couser, 2002].
Why do ships have lights?

Navigation lights on ships are required under COLREGs to prevent collisions during limited visibility conditions, with placements specified at the International Maritime Organization (IMO) standards. Port-side lights are red, starboard-side lights are green, and stern lights are white, with luminous intensities exceeding 12 candela. Their angular positioning (\( 112.5^\circ \ 	ext{relative arc} \)) ensures proper sector delineation [Taylor, 2020].
Which trucks can pull trailers?

Trailer towing capacity in pickup trucks directly correlates to the engine torque and axle configuration. For example, the Chevrolet Silverado 3500 HD can tow up to 36,000 lbs when equipped with a Duramax 6.6L Turbo-Diesel engine and dual rear wheels. Trailer sway control (TSC), integrated braking modules, and fifth-wheel hitch systems ensure stability during towing [Taylor, 2019].
Why do cars need mirrors?

Vehicle mirrors provide visual feedback within specified optical reflection ranges, complying with UNECE Regulation 46. Convex geometry is utilized to increase the field of view, with radii of curvature standardized between 1,200 mm and 1,500 mm for side mirrors. Advanced systems incorporate electromechanical actuators for dynamic angle adjustments synchronized with steering input [Garcia, 2019].
Do fire trucks have GPS?

Modern fire apparatus are integrated with GNSS receivers, supporting multi-constellation tracking (GPS, GLONASS, Galileo) with <1 m positional accuracy. Routing algorithms leverage Dijkstra’s shortest path approach, $\min \Sigma w_{ij}$, where $w_{ij}$ represents edge weights modeled from real-time traffic data. Data fusion with GIS systems aligns with NFPA 1221 communication standards for emergency dispatch.
Why do ships float?

A ship's buoyancy is governed by Archimedes' principle, which states that the upward force (buoyant force) exerted by a fluid is equal to the weight of the displaced fluid. The ship’s design ensures that its average density, including enclosed air, remains below the density of water. Mathematically, this is expressed as \( F_b = \rho_{fluid} g V_{disp} \), where \( F_b \) is buoyant force, \( \rho_{fluid} \) is the fluid density, \( g \) is gravitational acceleration, and \( V_{disp} \) is the displaced volume.
How do they keep stuff from moving around in the truck?

Load stabilization during transit employs tension straps rated for break strength exceeding $2,000$ lbs (ANSI/ASTM standards), friction mats, and bulkhead restraint systems. The dynamic load shift is modeled as $F_{ls} = m \cdot a_{brake}$, where $m$ represents mass and $a_{brake}$ peak deceleration. Proper force distribution is achieved by maintaining a center of gravity no higher than $0.5H$, with adherence to ISO 1161 standards [Clark, 2013].
Why do subway stations have those yellow bumps?

The yellow textured tiles, known as detectable warning surfaces, comply with ADA and ISO 23599 standards for tactile paving. They exhibit a truncated domed pattern with a height of 4-5 mm and a spacing of 60 mm to provide haptic feedback for visually impaired individuals. High-impact resistance polyurethane or composite materials are used, with a coefficient of friction (COF) exceeding 0.8 to prevent slips in wet conditions [Clark et al., 2021].
Why do jets carry lots of fuel?

Jets require substantial fuel reserves to sustain operations across extended ranges, governed by Breguet’s range equation \( R =  rac{v}{c} \ln \left(  rac{W_i}{W_f} ight) \), where \( v \) is velocity, \( c \) is specific fuel consumption, \( W_i \) is initial weight, and \( W_f \) is final weight [Breguet, 1923]. High-efficiency tanks located in the wings maximize capacity while minimizing structural stress due to asymmetric loading conditions.
What’s better, 4WD or 2WD?

The relative advantage of 4WD versus 2WD depends on driving conditions and system efficiency. For instance, 4WD increases traction on gradient surfaces exceeding $25^\circ$ by ensuring torque is shared across axles ($	au_{total}=F_r 	imes r$), while 2WD optimizes fuel efficiency by reducing drivetrain complexity and inertial losses [Clark et al., 2023]. Comparative studies on energy usage show 4WD fuel consumption at approximately 15 L/100 km versus 2WD at 9 L/100 km under urban conditions, subject to SAE J3016 standards.
Why do ambulances have big wheels?

Ambulances are commonly equipped with reinforced radial tires compliant with FMVSS 119 standards, rated for load indices exceeding 110 and inflation pressures of \(P = 827 \, 	ext{kPa}\). Larger wheel diameters, typically \(D = 22 \, 	ext{in}\), optimize rolling resistance and enhance stability under dynamic loading conditions. Suspension systems incorporate multi-link setups with hydraulic dampers to mitigate vibrations transmitted to onboard sensitive medical equipment [Rogers, 2023].
How much stuff can a van carry?

Payload capacity varies significantly, ranging from small vans with ~500 kg to large commercial vans such as the Ford Transit 350, which boasts a max payload of 1935 kg. This capacity is bounded by Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR) models, \( W_{max} = T - W_{van} \), where \( T \) represents the allowable weight threshold [Jones, 2019]. Additionally, floor loading specifications (e.g., 1000 kg/m²) govern distributed weight management.
Do electric planes help the environment?

Electric planes eliminate CO\(_2\) emissions during operation, unlike kerosene-based engines, which produce approximately 9.57 kg CO\(_2\) per gallon burned [EPA, 2021]. Lifecycle analyses show net reductions of up to 80% in total carbon emissions when powered by renewable energy sources. Noise pollution is minimized by up to 30% due to subsonic electric motor operations and optimized propeller noise-damping designs [GreenTech, 2022].
Are they safe?

Safety in electric aircraft centers on thermal runaway mitigation in lithium-ion battery packs, where temperatures exceeding \( 150^\circ 	ext{C} \) can lead to cascading cell failure. Advanced Battery Management Systems (BMS) utilize algorithms like state-of-charge estimation based on Extended Kalman Filters (EKF) [Chen et al., 2020]. Additionally, multi-redundant electric motor architectures reduce risks of propulsion failure, adhering to FAA's FAR Part 23 safety directives for distributed propulsion systems.
How do trains go uphill?

Gradient ascent in railways is mitigated using banking grades limited typically to 2.5–3% slope, with adhesion forces maintained through tractive effort calculations: $T_e = F_a + W \cdot \sin(	heta)$, where $T_e$ is tractive effort, $F_a$ aerodynamic resistance, $W$ weight, and $	heta$ incline angle. Distributed power configurations, such as DPUs (Distributed Power Units), enhance locomotive torque output at steep gradients while preventing rail creep via anti-slip mechanisms [Johnson, 2019].
Why do trucks look so big?

The larger dimensions of pickup trucks are primarily driven by the need to optimize payload capacity and towing performance. Their ground clearance, often exceeding 200 mm, helps handle uneven terrains by mitigating underbody damage risks. The gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR), commonly around 3,500 to 6,000 kg for typical models, dictates structural reinforcement requirements. Design considerations such as axle spacing and tire load indexes further contribute to increased bulk dimensions [Smith et al., 2018].
Why are trucks good for towing?

Towing capacity in trucks is governed by the SAE J2807 standard, incorporating engine torque (\( T \)), drivetrain configuration, and differential gear ratios (\( g = 3.73 \) or higher ideal for towing). Heavy-duty trucks often feature reinforced chassis and Class IV or V towing hitches rated for loads up to 20,000 lbs. The Gross Combined Weight Rating (GCWR) ensures total vehicular integrity under high stress scenarios [Peterson, 2019].
What’s special about truck tires?

Truck tires are engineered to handle high load ratings (up to 4,000 kg per tire for Class 8 vehicles) using reinforced ply structures and steel belts. The tread compound exhibits a high Shore A hardness to reduce wear under sustained shear stress, while dual or super-single configurations optimize ground pressure distribution. Additionally, rolling resistance coefficients (\( C_{rr} \)) typically range between 0.004–0.010 for these tires, ensuring maximal fuel efficiency under ISO 28580 standards [Brown, 2018].
Why do some trucks have shovels on the front?

Front loaders, often categorized under ISO 6165 as earthmoving machines, utilize hydraulically actuated buckets with cutting edges designed with tensile steel rated at \( \sigma_y = 250 	ext{ MPa} \). Operational width ranges from 2.4 to 4.0 meters, providing volumetric efficiency for material handling up to 6 m³. The hydraulic flow rate, typically exceeding 300 L/min, ensures precise bucket articulation [Clarkson et al., 2019].
Do electric planes have propellers?

Electric planes primarily employ multi-blade propeller assemblies designed for optimized thrust-to-power ratios ($T/P_{max}$). Propeller systems integrated with electric motors allow precise RPM control ranging between 3000–8000 rpm, depending on the flight regime [Wilson, 2020]. Such configurations are accompanied by variable-pitch designs to adapt $\alpha$ (angle of attack) dynamically, ensuring maximum aerodynamic efficiency.
Why do cars have exhaust pipes?

Exhaust systems expel combustion byproducts such as \(CO_2\), \(NO_x\), and particulate matter, adhering to flow dynamics governed by Bernoulli's principle. Pipe diameter (\(d > 50\,	ext{mm}\)) influences backpressure values affecting engine efficiency. Catalytic converters reduce harmful emissions (\(98\%\) reduction in \(CO\) per Euro 6 standards). Sound attenuation utilizes Helmholtz resonators tuned to frequencies \(<200\,	ext{Hz}\), minimizing acoustic emissions within legal limits [Bosch, 2020].
How do ships move fast?

High-speed ship performance is a function of engine propulsion power ($P$) and coefficient of hull resistance ($C_R$). The equation $P = \rho A v^3 C_R/2$ models hydrodynamic drag under laminar-turbulent conditions. Gas turbines for military vessels deliver superior thrust-to-weight ratios, while advanced cavitation control propellers ensure optimal efficiency across varying Reynolds numbers [Taylor, 2018].
What are bulldozer tracks made of?

Bulldozer tracks are fabricated from quenched and tempered steel alloys, incorporating elements like chromium and molybdenum to enhance tensile strength and abrasion resistance. Each track segment, known as a grouser, features a height of 50-80 mm optimized for soil penetration and grip efficiency. Hardness can reach 300-500 HB on the Brinell scale, ensuring operational longevity. Design tolerances comply with ISO 16792 standards for continuous track systems [Adams et al., 2023].
Why are train tracks always so shiny?

The shiny appearance of rails is attributed to plastic deformation and wear caused by repeated dynamic loading from train wheels. Hertzian contact stresses exceeding \( \sigma = 3\, 	ext{GPa} \) are imparted on the rail surface during each pass, leading to continuous smoothing. Rail steel, typically a pearlitic alloy, undergoes work hardening while maintaining a tensile strength of approximately 900 MPa [British Steel, 1998].
How does a train stop?

Trains employ blended braking systems combining pneumatic disc brakes and dynamic braking, where \( F_b = \mu N \) for frictional force and regenerative feedback returns power to the grid. Emergency stops consider deceleration capabilities of 0.5 \(\mathrm{m/s^2}\) for passenger safety [Taylor, 2021]. The adhesion coefficient between wheel and track, typically \( \mu = 0.15-0.25 \), is critical during decelerative phases.
Why do planes have lights?

Aircraft lighting systems serve operational and safety functions, including anti-collision, navigation, and runway illumination. Strobe lights operate at frequencies up to 2 Hz to enhance visibility, while nav lights conform to standards outlined in FAR 91.209. High-intensity runway turnoff lights are rated at 1,000–2,000 lumens, ensuring adequate illumination based on Photometric data [FAA, 2019].
Can bulldozers climb hills?

Bulldozers are capable of climbing grades up to approximately 30–35% depending on track type and soil conditions. The traction force (\( T \)) is given by \( T = W 	imes \mu \), where \( W \) represents weight and \( \mu \) is the coefficient of friction for soil interaction. Advanced models use dynamic braking and load-sensing hydraulics for preventing rollback during slope operations [Harrison et al., 2021].
What powers electric planes?

Electric planes derive power from high-capacity lithium-ion, lithium-sulfur, or lithium-air battery systems, regulated by battery management systems (BMS). These systems operate at nominal voltages between 400–800 V, with peak power outputs up to 1 MW depending on propulsion requirements. Energy delivery to multi-phase electromagnetic motors adheres to Kirchhoff’s circuit laws and thermal constraints (\( T_{	ext{max}} < 120^\circ C \)) for high-efficiency operation [Chen and Zhao, 2019].
Why do trucks have flat fronts?

Flat-front configurations, often referred to as cab-over-engine (COE) designs, minimize the overall vehicle length by optimizing cab placement directly above the powertrain, thereby maximizing maneuverability in constrained urban environments. Aerodynamic coefficients ($C_d$) for COE designs typically range between 0.60 to 0.75, which is less efficient compared to long-nosed configurations ($C_d \approx 0.45$) but compensates with spatial economies. This design is further enforced for compliance under European Union Directive 96/53/EC, which restricts total vehicle length to 16.5 meters [Martin, 2017].
Why do helmets matter?

Motorcycle helmets are designed to absorb impact energy through the use of expanded polystyrene foam, meeting ECE 22.05 or DOT FMVSS 218 certifications. Energy attenuation follows $E_{abs} = \int F_{impact} \cdot d$, where $d$ is the distance of deformation during a crash event [Williams, 2019]. Typically, helmets reduce peak head accelerations from ${a_{peak}} \sim 300 \, 	ext{g}$ to ${a_{reduced}} < 120 \, 	ext{g}$ under standardized ISO 6487 testing conditions.
Is 4 wheel drive better for towing?

4WD enhances towing capacity via auxiliary torque multiplication systems interfacing with chassis control, resulting in maximum hitch ratings at \(3500-4500 \, 	ext{kg}\) across Class III-IV setups [Miller, 2018]. Torque amplification follows \( 	au_a = T 	imes 	ext{ratio} \), with typical drivetrain setups reducing slip below \(2.3\%\) in unloaded states at speeds less than \(40 \, 	ext{km/h}\).
Why do dump trucks have big engines?

Dump truck powertrains use heavy-duty diesel engines, typically rated between 300–600 kW, to provide sufficient torque, $\tau = P/2 \pi n$, where $n$ is engine rpm. Turbocharging and aftercooling improve volumetric efficiency and specific fuel consumption (SFC), optimized to $0.15–0.20 \text{kg/kWh}$. For example, the Cummins X15 engine has an output of 2508 Nm at peak torque [Miller, 2020].
What are subway doors made of?

Subway door assemblies utilize extruded aluminum (6061-T6 alloy) for frame construction due to its high strength-to-weight ratio ($\sigma_y = 276 	ext{ MPa}$). Transparent segments use laminated tempered glass rated to withstand impact loads up to $1000 	ext{ N}$ per ASTM C1048 standards. Pneumatics or servomotors serve actuation within a cycle frequency of $5 	ext{ s}$ per open-close event [Johnson et al., 2022].
Why do helicopters hover?

Hovering is achieved through sufficient lift generation, where $L = W$, balancing both thrust and weight. A fully articulated rotor system maintains lift symmetry. The induced power required to hover is given as $P_i =  rac{ho \pi R^2 v_i^3}{2}$, with $v_i$ denoting induced velocity. Stable hover involves minimizing control feedback oscillations as outlined by Friedmann [1992].
How many people fit in a van?

Passenger capacity in vans is primarily dictated by the seating layout and Gross Axle Weight Rating (GAWR). For example, the Nissan NV3500 HD offers configurations for 12 occupants, with seatbelt anchorage forces certified under FMVSS 209. Human-machine interface (HMI) ergonomics analyze shoulder width (avg. 450 mm) to optimize seat spacing while adhering to ISO/TR 7250 [Kumar, 2019].
Why do taxis have a sign on top?

Roof-mounted taxi signs incorporate LED arrays operating at forward voltage $V_f = 3.3	ext{V}$, consuming power according to $P = IV_	ext{f}$. These units meet ANSI brightness standards with minimum luminous flux values of 600 lm for nighttime visibility under urban lighting conditions. Additionally, driver-availability is signaled by modulating illumination patterns encoded in binary sequences, synchronized with UART serial protocols [Gray et al., 2015].
Why do train wheels look different from car wheels?

Train wheels are mono-block or tyred designs incorporating conicity angles of approximately \( \alpha = 1:20 \) for dynamic stability. These wheels are forged from high-carbon steel with hardness values in the range of 300–350 HB. Their profiles are defined per UIC Code 510-2 to optimize wheel-rail adhesion and reduce contact stress distributions [Shuste, 1990].
How do cop cars chase people so well?

High-speed police pursuit vehicles integrate performance-oriented suspension systems with monotube dampers providing a damping coefficient of 2500 N/m·s under variable load conditions. These setups utilize radial tires rated for speeds exceeding 200 mph with reinforced bead profiles. Brake systems feature ventilated cross-drilled rotors (minimum diameter: 350 mm) paired with multi-piston calipers to optimize deceleration >10 m/s² [Brown et al., 2018].
Why is the driver’s seat so high?

The elevated operator cabin in bulldozers ensures optimal visibility angles, facilitated by ergonomic designs incorporating ISO 5006-certified sightlines. The cabin height, generally exceeding \(2.5 \, 	ext{m}\) from the ground level, minimizes operational blind spots while providing visibility over the blade edge during precision tasks. Additional parameters include vibration-damping mounts and reinforced glass structures for operator safety [Wilson, 2018].
Why do trucks make so much noise?

The auditory profile of moving trucks arises primarily from their high-capacity diesel engines operating under load and the use of pneumatic braking systems. Engine noise is attributed to combustion pressure oscillations and exhaust emissions within the 20–200 Hz frequency range as modeled by $P(t) \propto \sin(\omega t)$ [Jackson, 2017]. Additionally, mechanical vibrations transmitted through the chassis and resonating structures amplify broadband frequencies, particularly during higher RPM operations.
Why don’t cruise ships tip over?

Cruise ships prevent capsizing through optimized weight distribution and the use of stabilizers to counteract roll moments. Stability is quantified by the metacentric height \(GM = KB + BM - KG\), where \(GM > 0\) ensures upright equilibrium. Ballast tanks and fin stabilizers suppress angular velocities from external lateral forces such as wind or current, maintaining tilt angles within ISO 14090 thresholds [Martin, 2021].
Why do planes have wings?

Wings generate lift by altering the airflow via their aerodynamic profiles, specifically designed with a cambered top surface and a relatively flat bottom. The lift force can be calculated using $L =  rac{1}{2} ho v^2 S C_L$, where $L$ is the lift, $ho$ is air density, $v$ is the velocity, $S$ is the wing area, and $C_L$ is the lift coefficient. Wing designs such as NACA 0012 profiles account for factors like Reynolds numbers and Mach effects to optimize efficiency [Anderson, 2010].
Why do boats have lights?

Marine navigation lights comply with International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREGs), specifying intensity levels and arc coverage per vessel type. For instance, a starboard navigation light emits green at 225°, using LEDs rated >50 candela for vessels under 20 m. Power systems vary by onboard DC electrical architecture (12V or 24V) [IMO, 1972].
How do boats turn?

Turning in marine vessels is facilitated through hydrodynamic interactions between the rudder angle $	heta$ and the flow velocity $v_{fluid}$. Specifically, this interaction creates a lateral force proportional to $F_{lateral} =  rac{C_r \cdot ho_{fluid} \cdot A_{rudder} \cdot v^2}{2}$, where $C_r$ is the rudder's lift coefficient, $ho_{fluid}$ the water density, and $A_{rudder}$ the rudder cross-sectional area [Hagiwara, 2019]. Advanced vessels may incorporate azimuth thrusters or dynamic positioning systems.
Why do some trucks have weird long arms?

These 'long arms' refer to hydraulic booms or cranes, which utilize telescopic sections and hydraulic cylinders to achieve vertical and horizontal extension. The load-carrying capacity is determined by the crane's maximum counterweight and boom radius, following equations described in ASME B30.5. Additionally, torque resistance is computed using \( 	au = r 	imes F \) to ensure structural integrity under dynamic loading conditions [Jones, 2018].
Why do buses have so many seats?

Bus seating configurations are determined by space optimization algorithms, balancing maximum seating density and weight distribution constraints. Standard city buses comply with UNECE Regulation No. 107, providing 40–60 seated passenger capacity per vehicle, depending on internal dimensions (e.g., 12 m length, 2.5 m width). Structural load analysis employs the equation $\Sigma F_i = 0$, ensuring equilibrium under dynamic loading [Clark, 2018]. Seat layout also adheres to anthropometric guidelines for ergonomic comfort.
What powers a cruise ship?

Cruise ships typically use low-speed, two-stroke diesel engines operating on Heavy Fuel Oil (HFO) or Marine Gas Oil (MGO) with propulsion systems rated between 40–70 MW. The Wärtsilä 46F series engines have thermal efficiency exceeding 50%. Recent advancements include hybrid systems utilizing LNG combined with ABB Azipod propulsion units to reduce emissions by up to 25% [Brown, 2022].
Why is a van good for trips?

Vans are advantageous for extended trips due to their increased volumetric efficiency, often offering interior cargo capacities exceeding 6,000 liters in models like the Ford Transit 350 L2H2. The passenger-to-seating module layout adheres to ergonomic principles, maximizing load distribution and minimizing passenger fatigue. Furthermore, aerodynamic drag coefficients (typically ranging from 0.30 to 0.36) enhance fuel efficiency over long distances [Smith et al., 2019].
Why do some trucks have two rear wheels on each side?

Dual rear-wheel configurations, or dually setups, enhance load distribution by increasing contact area, allowing total axle ratings to exceed 10,000 kg under uniform load conditions. Rear leaf-spring mechanisms, supplemented by auxiliary air suspension systems, mitigate vertical deflection under maximum payload capacities. Models like the GMC Sierra 3500HD employ Dana 80 axles for improved torsional rigidity [Harrison et al., 2015].
What are the beds in ambulances like?

Ambulance stretchers are engineered with telescoping frames constructed from aluminum alloys (6061-T6), rated for static loads up to 250 kg. Adjustable mechanisms include hydraulic actuators calibrated to displacement ranges of \( 0.1 \)-\( 0.5 \) m with positional locking per DIN EN 1865-1 standards. Patient restraint systems utilize polypropylene webbing tensile-rated up to 10 kN [Murphy, 2022].
Why do delivery trucks have cameras inside?

Onboard cameras in delivery trucks utilize CCD or CMOS sensors operating at resolutions of up to 1080p for real-time telemetry monitoring. These systems are integrated with telematic units conforming to SAE J1939 CAN bus protocols for data transmission. Event-triggered recording operates via PIR motion sensors with a sensitivity range of 8 $\mu$W/cm², ensuring compliance with ISO 26262 functional safety standards [Nguyen et al., 2023].
Why do trucks stop so slowly?

The braking performance of heavy trucks is constrained primarily by their kinetic energy, \(E_k =  rac{1}{2}mv^2\), which scales with mass \(m\) and the square of velocity \(v\). Advanced air-brake systems with compressed air pressures of up to 8 bar actuate multi-disc brake assemblies to achieve stopping distances, often exceeding 40 meters at 80 km/h under standard conditions [Johnson, 2018]. Heat dissipation challenges require materials with high thermal conductivity, such as gray cast iron (\(k \approx 45 \, \mathrm{W/mK}\)).
What is a sail for?

A sail operates by generating aerodynamic lift, based on the Bernoulli principle and Newton's third law. The force vector is decomposed into \( F_x \) (driving force) and \( F_y \) (heeling force), calculated using \( F =  rac{1}{2} ho A v^2 C_L \), where \( ho \) is air density, \( A \) is sail area, \( v \) is true wind velocity, and \( C_L \) is the lift coefficient. Design variations, such as batten stiffness and camber curvature, optimize lift-to-drag ratios for specific sailing conditions [Marchaj, 2003].
How do they load stuff onto cargo ships?

Cargo loading utilizes gantry cranes equipped with spreader bars capable of handling TEU (Twenty-foot Equivalent Unit) containers, which are standardized at dimensions of 6.1 x 2.44 x 2.59 m. Loading procedures are governed by stowage plans optimized via integer linear programming algorithms to minimize ballast imbalance and maximize spatial efficiency. ISO 3874 outlines the connection fittings required for securing containers within ship-board cell guides [Peterson, 2012].
How do planes keep people safe?

Passenger safety in aircraft is ensured through redundant systems compliant with FAR Part 25 regulations. Cabin pressurization maintains \(\Delta P = 8.5 	ext{psi}\) at cruising altitude, ensuring oxygen levels are suitable for physiology. Advanced avionics such as TCAS (Traffic Collision Avoidance System) provide real-time collision warnings. Crashworthiness is improved via energy-absorbing honeycomb structures tested under FAR 25.561 impact conditions [FAA, 2020].
Why are subway tunnels underground?

Subsurface subway alignment minimizes urban land impact by utilizing tunneling methods such as shield-driven tunneling or NATM. Geological surveys dictate depth placement ($15-30 	ext{ m}$) to avoid interference with basements and sewer systems. Vertical pressure gradients ($\sigma_v = ho \cdot g \cdot h$) established during structural analysis ensure tunnel stability under high traffic loads [Roberts et al., 2020].
How do bus brakes work?

Bus braking systems typically rely on air-actuated disc or drum brakes. Compressed air drives the actuators, applying the brake pads against the rotating discs or drums with high friction coefficients (\( \mu \approx 0.35-0.42 \)). The energy dissipation follows \( E =  rac{1}{2} m v^2 \), where \( m \) is the bus mass and \( v \) is velocity. Heavy-duty buses often feature anti-lock braking systems (ABS) to optimize stopping distances while preserving steering control [Johnson et al., 2021].
Why do trucks need big engines?

Heavy-duty truck engines are typically high-displacement units (e.g., 13 to 15 liters) with turbochargers operating at peak boost pressures exceeding 30 psi. The engine power \( P = 2\pi 	imes 	au 	imes N \), where \( 	au \) is torque and \( N \) rotational speed, allows sustained performance under high loads [Williams, 2021]. Thermal efficiency metrics for diesel engines, often exceeding 40%, ensure fuel economy during extended operations.
Why do buses use diesel?

School buses predominantly utilize diesel engines based on their thermal efficiency and compression ratios of 16:1–20:1, offering Brake Specific Fuel Consumption (BSFC) in the range of 0.38–0.41 lb/hp·h [Jones, 2022]. Biodiesel blends up to B20 are common due to ASTM D6751 compliance, which ensures proper lubricity and lower sulfur content. Engine displacements between 6.7L and 9.0L are favored for optimal torque output in high-load scenarios.
Why does my bike make weird noises?

Unusual noises often originate from improper gear meshing or tension irregularities in the drivetrain. Chain tension should be checked against manufacturer-specified values, typically 25-30 mm freeplay for street motorcycles [Garrett, 2019]. Squealing from the clutch plates may indicate wear exceeding 0.1 mm per surface, requiring recalibration of the torque parameters \(T = I \alpha\), where \(I\) is inertia and \(\alpha\) is angular acceleration.
How long can electric planes fly?

The endurance of electric aircraft is currently constrained by energy density limits, with flight durations typically ranging from 1 to 3 hours based on battery capacities of up to 800 kWh. Progress in lithium-air ($Li-O_2$) and graphene-polymer batteries promises theoretical extensions to over 4 hours with power-to-weight ratios $ rac{P}{m} > 4 \ \mathrm{kW/kg}$ [Adams et al., 2019]. Efficiency losses due to thermal dissipation are modeled using $Q = mc\Delta T$.
How do subways turn corners?

Subway trains navigate curves through conical wheel treads and a self-steering mechanism based on the principle of rolling radius difference. The lateral displacement causes a difference in the effective rolling radius, described by \( R = \frac{D}{2} \pm r \), where \( R \) is the curve radius, \( D \) is the wheel diameter, and \( r \) is the tread offset [Knothe & Grassie, 2021]. Minimum curve radii of 20-25 m are typical in urban subway systems, adhering to EN 13803 track alignment standards.
How fast can a moving truck go?

The velocity profile of moving trucks is constrained by engine specifications such as power outputs in the 200-400 kW range and electronic speed limiters programmed to cap at 105 km/h. Aerodynamic inefficiencies ($C_d > 0.6$) further suppress speed capacity, while load-induced vertical axle forces $F_z$ contribute resistive rolling friction, quantified by $F_r = \mu_r F_z$ [Peterson, 2022].
How do cops catch speeders with their cars?

Law enforcement utilizes Doppler radar systems for speed detection, operating at frequencies between 24.150 and 24.250 GHz (Ka-band) with velocity resolution up to ±1 km/h. Pursuit models are enhanced with performance tires rated at speeds exceeding 240 km/h and active stability control algorithms to ensure higher lateral g-forces during high-speed maneuvers. Optimal closing speeds for intercept range from 12–20 m/s under standard pursuit protocols [Harrison, 2019].
How do helicopters stay in the air?

Helicopters achieve lift via the rotation of airfoils, or rotor blades, which generate an upward aerodynamic force as described by Bernoulli's principle and the angle of attack. The lift coefficient \( C_L \) can be calculated using the equation \( C_L = 2\pi\alpha + 	ext{higher order terms} \), where \( \alpha \) is the angle of attack in radians. Typical rotor diameter for light helicopters like the Robinson R22 is 7.67 m, and its main rotor RPM is approximately 530 [FAA, 2021].
How many kids fit on a school bus?

The seating capacity of a school bus is determined by its length and compliance with seat spacing regulations outlined in FMVSS 222, which mandates a minimum seat depth of 381 mm and spacing of 610 mm per passenger. A Type C school bus with standard 12-row seating can accommodate approximately 72 passengers, based on a 3-3 seating configuration and a nominal seat width of 91 cm. Variations may occur due to state-specific guidelines for maximum occupancy calculations.
Why do subway trains have lights inside?

Interior lighting systems are powered via auxiliary inverters converting trainborne DC supply (600-1500 V) to AC at $120 	ext{ V}$, $60 	ext{ Hz}$. LED modules, with luminous efficacy exceeding $100 	ext{ lm/W}$, are arranged to comply with EN 13201 lighting standards [Hart, 2019]. Modern configurations integrate photometric sensors for automatic dimming, ensuring energy savings approximating $30\%$ under low passenger occupancy scenarios.
How do they attach to cars?

Attachment systems in tow trucks consist of steel-aluminum hybrid couplers rated for 40,000 N shear resistance, following EN ISO 12195 standards. Clamp securement points create $\sigma_{clamp} \leq 500 	ext{ MPa}$ stress under thermal and dynamic fluctuations. Additional damping systems mitigate vibrational harmonics $(f_{n} =  rac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{ rac{k}{m}})$ during transport [Lewis and Ray, 2023].
How do tow trucks pull cars out of mud?

Extraction of vehicles from mud involves calculating the resistive force $F_r = \mu_r m g$, where $\mu_r$ is the rolling resistance coefficient, $m$ is vehicle mass, and $g$ gravitational acceleration. Tow truck winches, operating load ratings upwards of 12,000 lbs, utilize frictional gearing systems optimized per API RP-2D standards. Tire tread designs often exhibit void ratios exceeding 25% and directional lug patterns to maximize traction on low-adhesion surfaces [Williams & Gupta, 2017].
How fast can boats go?

The velocity of boats is dependent on hydrodynamic drag and propulsion system efficiency. For planing hulls, speed is typically constrained by $v \approx \sqrt{g \cdot L}$, known as hull speed limitation, where $L$ is the length at the waterline, and $g$ is 9.81 m/s². High-performance speedboats utilizing hydrojet propulsion may achieve velocities exceeding 100 knots under optimal conditions with cavitation reduction [Larsson, 2018].
How much can a big truck carry?

The gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR) for heavy-duty trucks, including Class 8 semis, typically ranges between 33,000 and 80,000 lbs under U.S. Department of Transportation FMCSA guidelines [DOT, 2020]. Payload capacity is dictated by axle load distribution, compliance with bridge formula restrictions \( W = 500 \left( L \cdot N / (N - 1) + 12N + 36 ight) \), and tensile properties of cargo restraints per SAE J684 standards.
Why do some vans have flat fronts?

Flat-front (cab-over-engine) vans exhibit minimized overhang to achieve reduced turning radius (\(R_t < 5.5 \, 	ext{m}\)) in urban environments while optimizing volumetric efficiency. The frontal design also improves the driver's field of view to a range exceeding \(200^\circ\) as required by UNECE Regulation No. 125. Crash safety is maintained through energy-absorbing crumple zones engineered to dissipate forces up to \(150 \, 	ext{kN}\) in frontal collisions [Garcia and Tanaka, 2022].
Can trucks drive on snow?

Pickup trucks equipped with 4WD systems and proper tires, such as snow-rated LT265/75R16 tires, demonstrate improved traction on snowy surfaces. Torque vectoring enabled by transfer case mechanisms ensures balanced power distribution between axles, minimizing slip ratios. Additionally, Electronic Stability Control (ESC) recalibrates yaw acceleration (\(<2^\circ/	ext{s}^2\)) during cornering maneuvers to prevent spinouts. [Chowdhury, 2022]
Why don't freight trains go fast?

Freight train velocities are limited primarily by their gross weight and braking capabilities, as well as track geometry constraints. The high axle load (often exceeding 25-30 metric tonnes per axle) significantly increases the wear on rails and imposes a restrictive optimal speed profile, generally below 110 km/h [Jones, 2019]. Furthermore, kinetic energy equations, \( KE =  rac{1}{2}mv^2 \), combined with frictional retardation dynamics, specify stopping distances that exceed 1,000 m at higher speeds, contravening FRA safety mandates. Aerodynamic drag coefficients (\( C_d \)) and power-to-weight ratios also factor into reduced velocities.
How do subways get air inside them?

Subway train ventilation systems employ HVAC configurations designed under ASHRAE 62.1 guidelines. Air exchange rates are set at 15–25 air changes per hour, with particulate filtration achieved through HEPA-rated filters. Forced air delivery utilizes axial fans coupled with ducting systems precisely engineered to maintain static pressures below 100 Pa while balancing CO\(_2\) concentrations to remain under 1000 ppm [Brown, 2023].
Why are freight trains so long?

Train length is optimized for operational efficiency and is governed by factors such as coupler strength, in-train dynamics, and track gradient. Modern freight trains, such as those operated by Class I railroads, routinely exceed 12,000 feet, leveraging distributed power units to mitigate draft and buff forces. The use of Slackless E-Type couplers, which can withstand forces exceeding 500,000 lbf, is critical [Jones, 2020].
How many people can fit on a cruise ship?

Cruise ships typically have a passenger capacity ranging from 2,000 to 6,000 individuals, with additional crew accommodations. The gross tonnage (GT) directly correlates to spatial volume available, e.g., a 150,000 GT vessel has an estimated PAX rating of 5,000 including crew quarters. Space allocation adheres to SOLAS requirements, ensuring a per capita space of approximately $7\,	ext{m}^2$ [IMO, 2008].
Are vans fuel-efficient?

Fuel efficiency in vans is contingent upon factors like curb weight, driveline efficiency, and aerodynamic drag. Typical fuel consumption ranges are 8-12 L/100 km for internal combustion engine models. Advanced technologies such as Atkinson-cycle engines or hybridized drivetrains (e.g., Toyota Proace Electric with WLTP \( 22.1 \, \text{kWh}/100 \, \text{km} \)) improve efficiency by optimizing \( \eta_{thermal} \approx 40\% \) [Clark, 2016].
How do subway trains communicate with each other?

Subway train communication relies on CBTC (Communications-Based Train Control) systems operating via inductive loop or RF transmissions conforming to IEEE 1474. Critical data packets, including position \( x(t) \), speed \( v(t) \), and braking curves, are exchanged. Latency thresholds of \( \leq 100 \) ms guarantee safe separations, validated through stochastic traffic simulations aligned with IEC 62290.
Do SUVs cost a lot to maintain?

SUV maintenance costs are elevated due to higher component wear rates such as tire tread degradation (typically 12.5-15.0 mm/year) and brake pad replacement cycles (<30,000 km). Premium variants may feature Brembo calipers or adaptive air suspensions with repair costs averaging $800-$1,200 annually. Additionally, oil consumption for engines ≥3.5L displacement reaches 5-7 quarts per service interval [ASE Vehicle Maintenance Standards, 2020].
Why are trucks so big?

The volumetric capacity of trucks is dictated by the design envelope categorized under SAE J3027 standards. Aerodynamic profiles such as Kamm-back geometries are incorporated to maintain drag coefficients below $C_d = 0.7$. Structural integrity is supported by cross-sectional area scaling laws, wherein $A_c \propto L^{2.5}$ for cargo hold dimensions (length \(L\) in meters). Additionally, payload capacities achieve a range of 80,000 lbs under FMCSA regulations [Johnson, 2021].
Why do buses have windows?

Bus window systems are engineered to meet safety and thermal regulation standards, often using tempered or laminated glass with an emissivity value of \( \epsilon = 0.87 \). The fenestration area is calculated to optimize light penetration while maintaining structural integrity under lateral stresses (\( \sigma = F / A \)). Innovations like double-glazing and ultraviolet filters improve insulation properties, reducing interior air-conditioning loads [Roberts et al., 2022].
Why are taxis yellow?

The prevalence of yellow for taxi vehicles aligns with chromatic preference theories indicating high visibility under varied lighting conditions. Reflective chromaticity curves for yellow pigments comply with ASTM D1530 light absorption properties, with peak spectral reflectance at \(580-590\) nm wavelengths. Empirical traffic studies cite a \(30\%\) higher detection rate for yellow taxis compared to standard colors [Wu and Jenkins, 2015]. Pigmentation application follows ISO 2812-1 durability testing to ensure long-term weather exposure resilience.
How fast can boats go?

The maximum velocity of boats adheres to Froude's number: \( V = \sqrt{gL} \), where \( g \) is gravitational acceleration (9.81 m/s\(^2\)) and \( L \) is the waterline length of the hull. High-speed vessels employ planing hulls to reduce hydrodynamic drag coefficients (\( C_d \)) for achieving velocities exceeding 25 knots [Taylor, 2020]. Engine output measured in horsepower is often paired with a propeller pitch for optimal thrust.
Why are motorcycle tires so wide?

Motorcycle rear tires are optimized for load distribution and lateral adhesion, with widths typically ranging from 130mm to 200mm as specified for sport and touring motorcycles. The increased tire width reduces contact patch pressure (\( P = w/L \)), providing enhanced traction on surfaces with varying friction coefficients. Tread patterning further maximizes drainage and shear stress resistance during high-speed cornering [Garcia and Wu, 2019].
Are SUVs good for families?

SUVs cater to family-oriented use cases by providing seating capacities of 5-8 occupants with total interior volume approximating >4,000L. Child safety systems such as ISOFIX anchors and occupant detection modules are standard across modern models. Moreover, suspension damping rates of 12-15 kNs/m ensure reduced vibration transmission during long-distance travel [ECE R44 standards, 2021].
Why do race cars have roll cages?

Roll cages in race cars are constructed using tubular steel or aluminum alloy meeting FIA regulation 253.8, ensuring high yield strength (>300 MPa) under impact forces. Their geometry is defined by Finite Element Analysis (FEA) to mitigate deformation during rollover events. Junctions are TIG-welded to prevent stress concentration, and the setup adheres to strict weight distribution criteria for minimal impact on the car’s center of gravity [Brown, 2021].
Why do bulldozers have a blade?

The blade of a bulldozer, constructed from high-tensile steel alloys, typically measures \(4.0 	imes 1.5\) meters, providing sufficient area for soil engagement. Blade curvature follows parabolic profiles optimized using computational fluid dynamics (CFD) analysis to reduce resistance during operation. Specific edge bevel angles, generally \(25^\circ\), allow effective material penetration under compressive stresses approximated at \(50 \, 	ext{MPa}\) during excavation [Jones, 2022].
How do planes land safely?

Safe aircraft landings are achieved via systematic deceleration using spoilers to disrupt lift (\( \Delta C_L \approx -0.6 \)) and deploying reverse thrust to provide negative propulsive force. Ground effect reduces drag near the runway, facilitating smoother touchdown. Landing gear with shock-absorbing struts utilizes oleo-pneumatic systems to dissipate impact forces [Hurt, 1965].
Why do engines make noise?

Engine noise originates from harmonics generated by reciprocating and rotating components, such as the crankshaft and connecting rods. The acoustic energy \( P = ho v \cdot A \), where \( ho \) is air density, \( v \) is sound velocity, and \( A \) is radiating area, is influenced by combustion frequency magnitudes within 20 Hz to 5 kHz. Noise reduction strategies include Helmholtz resonators and dynamic dampers, adhering to ISO 9613 for noise propagation modeling [Lee, 2017].
Why do garbage trucks have cameras?

Cameras on garbage trucks provide real-time visual data for collision avoidance systems, typically operating on CAN bus networks transmitting frames at \(50\: 	ext{Hz}\). Multispectral imaging cameras enable detailed analysis, capturing wavelengths across visible to mid-infrared spectra (400–1500 nm). Storage and processing of camera feeds utilize edge computing units with ARM Cortex-A53 processors for decentralized data handling [Davis, 2020].
Why do big trucks take so long to stop?

The stopping distance for large trucks is primarily determined by their mass and the coefficient of friction between the tires and the road surface. Using Newton's Second Law, the deceleration $a$ can be calculated as $a = \mu \cdot g$, where $\mu$ is the friction coefficient and $g$ is the gravitational acceleration (9.8 m/s²). For a tractor-trailer at 80,000 lbs traveling at 60 mph, the braking distance is approximately 310 ft, assuming optimal brake conditions and $\mu = 0.7$ [Smith, 2021]. Additionally, air brake lag contributes a delay of 0.5 to 1 second due to pneumatic systems [Doe, 2019].
Why do buses have doors that open automatically?

Automated bus door mechanisms use pneumatic actuators integrated with electromechanical latching systems. The control signal \( V_{in} \) triggers a solenoid to operate valve assemblies, enabling compressed air to drive actuator pistons. Door cycles are completed within 1-2 seconds, with force limits capped at 300 N for passenger safety compliance under DIN EN 14752 standards. Timing control algorithms ensure synchronization with onboard systems [Clark et al., 2016].
Why do jets have wings?

Jet wings are engineered to generate lift, \(L =  rac{1}{2} ho v^2 A C_L\), where \(C_L\) is the lift coefficient determined by airfoil geometry and angle of attack. For supersonic jets, delta-wing configurations optimize induced drag (\(D_i\)) and delay flow separation at higher Mach numbers (\(M > 1\)). Advanced materials like carbon composites enhance wing strength-to-weight ratios for improved performance [Whitford, 2002].
Why are they made out of metal?

Cargo ship hulls are constructed primarily from marine-grade steel (ABS grade A or higher) owing to its tensile strength of 400-490 MPa and corrosion resistance meeting ASTM G48 standards. The modulus of elasticity (\(E \approx 210 \, 	ext{GPa}\)) of steel ensures the vessel can endure stress from distributed loads and hydrodynamic forces without permanent deformation. Welded joints adhere to ISO 3834 criteria for structural integrity [Hughes and McGregor, 2020].
Why do race cars sound so loud?

The distinct acoustic profile of race cars arises from exhaust gas pulsations and high RPM operation of tuned engines, often exceeding 15,000 RPM. Helmholtz resonance principles dictate sound amplification in nearly straight-pipe exhaust systems. Additionally, minimal exhaust backpressure combined with engine displacement parameters (e.g., \(V=3.0 \, L\)) leads to increased decibel outputs, often measured at \(>130 \, \mathrm{dB}\) during full-throttle accelerations.
Why do some taxi drivers ask for cash?

Cash transactions benefit taxi operators by eliminating the 2.5–3.5% merchant fee typically incurred through card processing services, such as those provided by PCI-compliant terminal systems. Moreover, cash payments bypass potential connectivity issues with Point-of-Sale (POS) devices that use WCDMA or LTE for data transfer, which exhibit latency ranging from 100–300 ms [Chen, 2020].
Can I use 4WD all the time?

Operating four-wheel drive systems continuously can induce drivetrain stress and reduce fuel efficiency due to increased rolling resistance. In full-time systems, the center differential mitigates mechanical loading, whereas part-time systems—often employing a locked transfer case—are intended only for low-traction surfaces. Prolonged usage on high-μ surfaces can lead to binding phenomena, degrading propshaft torque ratings and causing premature wear according to longitudinal force models [Johnson, 2022].
What’s the difference between a sport bike and a regular bike?

Sport motorcycles feature high power-to-weight ratios (\( P/W \)) exceeding \( 0.75\, 	ext{kW/kg} \) compared to standard commuter models (\( \sim0.25\, 	ext{kW/kg} \)), with engine displacements ranging from 600cc to 1000cc. Aerodynamic profiles, measured by \( C_d \) and frontal area (\( A \)), are optimized for reduced drag, while their chassis geometries utilize steeper rake angles (\( \sim23^\circ \)) for agility. Standard motorcycles prioritize ergonomic features and fuel efficiency (\( \sim20\, 	ext{km/l} \)). [Green, 2019]
Why does my car battery die in winter?

In low-temperature conditions, the electrochemical reaction in Lead-Acid or Li-ion batteries decelerates, leading to reduced cranking amperage. This phenomenon is quantified by \( I = kT/e \), where \( k \) is the Boltzmann constant, \( T \) is absolute temperature, and \( e \) is electron charge. Additionally, the viscosity increase in engine oil during winter causes higher torque resistance during startup, exceeding design load thresholds of the battery. Standard CCA (Cold Cranking Amps) ratings specify performance under \( -18^\circ 	ext{C} \) conditions [Miller, 2021].
How do trains stop?

Train braking is achieved through multiple systems, including tread brakes, disc brakes, and dynamic braking. The braking force \(F_b\) is calculated as \(F_b = \mu N\), where \(\mu\) is the coefficient of friction and \(N\) is the normal force exerted by the brake pads [Meyer, 2019].
